image.altText: Smoke rises from buildings.

items.synopsis: Hamas attacks leave more than 250 Israelis dead and 1,500 injured, with Israeli defence chiefs reportedly targeting the homes of six Hamas leaders inside Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: Israel's security forces target homes of Hamas leaders in retaliation to attacks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This is something analysts have said could constitute an escalation, but at this stage, the cross-border military fire is contained to the area that is very much contested by Hezbollah. Earlier, Reuters reported mortar fire from inside Lebanon into northern Israel. Now the agency is reporting the Israeli military has fired back. "IDF artillery is currently striking the area in Lebanon from where a shooting was carried out," Israeli forces announced. Security sources told Reuters projectiles launched from Lebanese territory hit an Israeli military position in the Israeli-occupied Shebaa farms early on Sunday. The sources said Israeli artillery fire then began hitting Lebanese territory.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Artillery fired over Lebanon-Israel border in the north

children.content: This is something analysts have said could constitute an escalation, but at this stage, the cross-border military fire is contained to the area that is very much contested by Hezbollah.
Earlier, Reuters reported mortar fire from inside Lebanon into northern Israel. Now the agency is reporting the Israeli military has fired back.
"IDF artillery is currently striking the area in Lebanon from where a shooting was carried out," Israeli forces announced.
Security sources told Reuters projectiles launched from Lebanese territory hit an Israeli military position in the Israeli-occupied Shebaa farms early on Sunday.
The sources said Israeli artillery fire then began hitting Lebanese territory.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Middle East correspondent Adam Harvey has reflected on the events of the past 24 hours. Writing analysis for ABC News he says: "Gaza is one of the most densely populated places on Earth: 2 million people squeezed into a space the size of a handful of suburbs in Sydney's east. It's also one of the most-heavily monitored - constantly watched by satellites and drones and Israeli agents and sources on the ground. "In such a place, it's extraordinary that not a hint of the planning for this operation was picked up. "After the Hamas fighters inside Israel have been caught or killed, after the inevitable Israeli ground assault into Gaza, and after the funerals of many Israelis and Palestinians who die in this conflict, there will be another wave of bloodletting. "It will involve the careers of the intelligence and military officials whose networks failed completely to detect a hint of this attack." Read his full analysis piece here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Analysis: Israeli failure opens door to Hamas attack

featuredLink.title: Israeli intelligence failure opens door to surprise Hamas attack

children.content: Former Middle East correspondent Adam Harvey
has reflected on the events of the past 24 hours.
Writing analysis for ABC News he says:

"Gaza is one of the most densely populated places on Earth: 2 million people squeezed into a space the size of a handful of suburbs in Sydney's east. It's also one of the most-heavily monitored - constantly watched by satellites and drones and Israeli agents and sources on the ground.
"In such a place, it's extraordinary that not a hint of the planning for this operation was picked up.
"After the Hamas fighters inside Israel have been caught or killed, after the inevitable Israeli ground assault into Gaza, and after the funerals of many
Israelis and Palestinians who die in this conflict, there will be another wave of bloodletting.
"It will involve the careers of the intelligence and military officials whose networks failed completely to detect a hint of this attack."
Read his full analysis piece here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's public broadcaster KAN News is reporting the Israel Defense Forces have hit the homes of six Hamas leaders inside Gaza. The list includes Yahya Sinwar, who is the leader of Hamas inside Gaza. There is no confirmation the individuals were at home at the time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel strikes homes of Hamas leaders: local media

children.content: Israel's public broadcaster KAN News is reporting the Israel Defense Forces have hit the homes of six Hamas leaders inside Gaza.
The list includes Yahya Sinwar, who is the leader of Hamas inside Gaza.
There is no confirmation the individuals were at home at the time.

image.altText: A photo of a man and a woman with their faces scribbled out.

items.synopsis: A letter from a stranger is all it took to spiral Martin into losing control of his own life. The disability royal commission has made recommendations to reform guardianship legislation, including gag laws that prevent Martin from speaking about his experience.

title.children: Martin isn't allowed to live at home or see his wife. A royal commission wants changes to help others like him

image.altText: Palestinians wave their national flag and celebrate.

items.synopsis: Gaza is one of the most heavily monitored places on earth, constantly watched by satellites and drones and agents on the ground. And yet, Israeli defence and intelligence had no idea Hamas's carefully coordinated assault was coming, writes Adam Harvey.

title.children: Israeli intelligence failure opens door to surprise Hamas attack

image.altText: A man wearing a broad-brimmed hat stands on a porch with one arm reaching up.

items.synopsis: When Yindjibarndi leader Michael Woodley stood his ground against Andrew Forrest's FMG he had no idea he'd still be fighting for compensation 14 years later. Despite community division and lengthy court battles he's never backed down.

title.children: 'Money, power and influence': One man's fight against Australia's richest man Andrew Forrest

image.altText: Crying child and father walk down road

items.synopsis: Israel says it is now at war with Hamas, launching air strikes on Gaza and vowing to inflict an "unprecedented price" after dozens of Hamas militants broke out of the blockaded Gaza Strip and into nearby Israeli towns, killing hundreds and abducting others in an unprecedented operation.

title.children: 'We are at war': Israel retaliates with Gaza strikes after Palestinian militants kill hundreds and take hostages

image.altText: A boy next to a burning vehicle.

items.synopsis: Israel is responding to the biggest Hamas attack in years, but the seeds of the unrest were sown decades ago.

title.children: Israel and Hamas 'at war': How did we get here and how is it playing out?

image.altText: Burnt debris is scattered on a bare field near a large gum tree.

items.synopsis: In a statement released through NSW Police, the family of Queensland pilot Peter Nally and his three grandchildren ask for privacy as they "grieve and process this tragedy".

title.children: 'No words to describe the grief': Family of pilot, three children killed in plane crash near Gundaroo ask for privacy

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: An irrigation channel.

items.synopsis: Australia's legacy cotton country is once again bone-dry, but some of the area's largest growers have set their sights on an unlikely part of Australia where the grass might just be greener.

title.children: Land values in a tiny patch of WA's outback skyrocket as big cotton moves in

items.synopsis: Australian law enforcement has started solving missing persons and unidentified remains cases using official police access to private genealogy databases, which combined, hold the DNA records of millions of people around the world.

title.children: It's being called the biggest game-changer in forensic investigations since DNA testing

image.altText: A woman stands next to a busy street while wearing headphones.

items.synopsis: The "silent walking" trend on TikTok has highlighted how much we rely on audio distractions to get us through the day. But is it a problem?

title.children: 'Me and my thoughts? Sounds horrible': What the 'silent walking' trend says about us

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese says the government will "respect the outcome of the referendum" if the Voice vote fails next weekend.

title.children: PM rules out legislating Voice if referendum fails

image.altText: A spacecrafts solar panel is visible in the foreground, a large grey orange asteroid in the background

items.synopsis: The Psyche mission will travel to an asteroid unlike any we've seen. Its investigations could shed light on how the Solar System and the planets formed.

title.children: This asteroid, worth an estimated $15,600 quadrillion, is the target of a new NASA mission

image.altText: Artist's impression of an asteroid collision with Earth.

items.synopsis: In 2020, Oxford philosopher Toby Ord put the chances of "existential catastrophe" for our species during the next century at one in six. But does it really stack up, asks Steven Stern.

title.children: Is there really a 1 in 6 chance of human extinction this century?

image.altText: An older Indigenous lady wears a blue dress and looks upwards as she places her elbow on a fridge

items.synopsis: As debate rages in remote communities about whether a Voice to Parliament will improve the lives of Indigenous Australians, leaders in WA's northern-most town hope it can lift the next generation out of hopelessness to a place of prosperity.

title.children: 'They want jobs, not handouts': Why locals say the Voice could break a vicious cycle in this outback town

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: The ABC's poll of the polls now puts Yes at an average of 41.2 per cent, well behind No at 58.8 per cent, Casey Briggs writes.

title.children: How is the Voice polling with less than a week to October 14?

image.altText: An elderly woman in a red headscarf stands in front of a wall of family photos

items.synopsis: Aunty Ruth Hegarty lived through a cruel chapter in Australian history. Now aged 94, she's approaching the Voice vote with optimism for future generations.

title.children: 'This is truth-telling': At 94, Ruth Hegarty wants to you to hear her story before you vote

image.altText: Two men sitting at a table, smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: Before he became Ukraine's commander-in-chief, Volodymyr Zelenskyy was never far from the front lines — these men were there with him, and know a different side to the president.

title.children: The men who know a different side to Volodymyr Zelenskyy

image.altText: A burnt-out shell of a car viewed from the front.

items.synopsis: The gunmen allegedly involved in yesterday's deadly shooting at a shopping centre in Melbourne's north remain on the run, as police reveal the attackers set two getaway cars on fire before fleeing in a third.

title.children: Police say two getaway vehicles set alight after 'frightening' daylight car park killing in Melbourne

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses, a dark face mask and brown dress makes her way through a press pack with cameras

items.synopsis: Jakarta's police are in the midst of a morality crackdown, raiding porn studios and targeting content creators. But adult performers say it won't do anything to stop Indonesians from accessing porn.

title.children: Siskaeee is Indonesia's best-known adult performer despite a ban on porn and risk of jail time

image.altText: Vertical gardens and a fountain.

items.synopsis: Singapore will soon join Dubai to provide travellers with a more efficient immigration clearance as early as 2024 following an update to its Immigration Bill.

title.children: Singapore goes passport-free as experts raise alarms on risks. But it's not the first country to do it

image.altText: a stretch of road with right turns and potholes

items.synopsis: Self-represented locals say the farmland flanking the city should not be lost to urban sprawl.

title.children: VCAT sides with residents to scrap hotel development on Ballarat's farming fringes

image.altText: Brodie Kostecki drives his car

items.synopsis: Defending champion Shane van Gisbergen may be in trouble, as the Bathurst 1000 edges closer to its finish at Mount Panorama. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: 'Brakes don't feel good': Bathurst 1000 contender strikes mechanical issue

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: 'I have a very low pedal," says Shane van Gisbergen on his outlap! "Brakes don't feel good." This could be a disaster for the defending champ. "Pumping is not helping." "Very, very low." Interesting stuff - that might be an issue that could be fixed if they change the caliper again at the next pit stop or will they try to hold things as they are? He says he's going to keep going but asks his team to warn him if there is any low pressure.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shane van Gisbergen has brake issues!

children.content: (Getty Images)
'I have a very low pedal," says Shane van Gisbergen on his outlap!
"Brakes don't feel good."
This could be a disaster for the defending champ.
"Pumping is not helping."
"Very, very low."
Interesting stuff - that might be an issue that could be fixed if they change the caliper again at the next pit stop or will they try to hold things as they are?
He says he's going to keep going but asks his team to warn him if there is any low pressure.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Golding has been held up by this! Another car has rally-crossed his way across the grass to get into the pits.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 72: MOFFATT HAS BLOCKED PIT ENTRY!

children.content: James Golding has been held up by this!
Another car has rally-crossed his way across the grass to get into the pits.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Moffatt has slammed into the wall at the dipper! Heavy contact too! He might have hit the inside wall and then slammed into the corner. It came just after the Brad Jones Racing entry of Dale Wood had an engine explode. It's going to bring the third safety car of the day out onto the circuit, but Moffatt is going to bring his car limping into the pits. Moffatt is doing very well to get this car back to the pits - there is a lot of damage. Both Red Bulls have come into the pits, David Russell is going through to reclaim the lead.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 71: Safety car!

children.content: James Moffatt has slammed into the wall at the dipper!
Heavy contact too!
He might have hit the inside wall and then slammed into the corner.
It came just after the Brad Jones Racing entry of Dale Wood had an engine explode.
It's going to bring the third safety car of the day out onto the circuit, but Moffatt is going to bring his car limping into the pits.
Moffatt is doing very well to get this car back to the pits - there is a lot of damage.
Both Red Bulls have come into the pits, David Russell is going through to reclaim the lead.

image.altText: Tevita Ikanivere and Ilaisa Droasese clap

items.synopsis: The Rugby World Cup has been an unmitigated disaster for the Wallabies but they can still qualify for the quarterfinals. Here's how.

title.children: How the Wallabies can qualify for the World Cup quarterfinals

image.altText: a group of men stand around on rubble

items.synopsis: A magnitude-6.3 earthquake followed by strong aftershocks kills dozens of people in Afghanistan's west.

title.children: Powerful earthquake and aftershocks kill dozens and injure many more in western Afghanistan

image.altText: scaffolding around building next to crane

items.synopsis: As suburban sprawl radiates from cities across the country, experts say Australia needs more infill development. But building higher-density homes isn't always easy.

title.children: There's a bunch of issues impacting Australia's housing crisis. Then there's the 'Nimby Paradox'

image.altText: A man holds a bundle of raw hemp fire.

items.synopsis: Hemp is one of the toughest plants on the planet and its potential uses range from bulletproof vests in the US to waterproof flooring for housing and other robust building products in Australia.

title.children: The bulletproof plant undergoing high-velocity growth

image.altText: Sun setting over Indian Ocean

items.synopsis: Climate researchers at the Bureau of Meteorology hope a new system will prevent situations where some agencies are declaring an El Niño event and others aren't.

title.children: Weather scientists worry fast-warming oceans have warped BoM's El Niño index

image.altText: A man holding his licence in a park

items.synopsis: When Ben was scammed out of footy tickets, he had no idea the people who duped him were about to use his identity to ruin his reputation and scam even more people — including those desperate for Taylor Swift tickets.

title.children: Ben barely knows Taylor Swift's music, but people falsely believe he scammed the artist's concert tickets

image.altText: Seven Australian players group together as they celebrate a wicket against West Indies in the women's ODI in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: Chasing a paltry victory target of just 84 runs, the world champions record a comfortable eight-wicket win in the first ODI against West Indies at Brisbane's Allan Border Field.

title.children: Aussies cruise to victory over Windies in ODI series opener

image.altText: Lady in costume made out of ghost nets

items.synopsis: From striking art installations to one-of-a-kind costumes, two designers are transforming marine debris into "beautiful things" that highlight a scourge that plagues our beaches.

title.children: Ghost nets come alive in a sardine-packed fashion spectacular
